subject: Re: A case for adding logging of assertions to junit
msgSnippet: The log is not important. Feel free to skip it. If, however, you find yourself a little mystified about your test case s behaviour, you have the option of
messageBody:
The log is not important. Feel free to skip it.

If, however, you find yourself a little mystified about your
test case's behaviour, you have the option of turning on
the log to get another view on what the test case is doing.
Alternately you could run the test in a debugger. Or you could
start writing a bunch of hand-crafted logging statements since
logging is sometimes more effective than debugging.
But in some cases the assertion log would already be logging what
you need to know without your having to write those statements.

It's just another tool that is sometimes useful. Debuggers
are important, but you don't have to use them.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Wenner <robert.wenner@...> wrote:
>
> On Monday 09 June 2008 21:18, CÃ©dric Beust wrote:
> > > If I have to go through umpteen thousand lines of log, I may as well
> > > test everything manually.
> >
> > Nobody says you have to, but the fact that your tests pass doesn't
> > guarantee that you are testing what you think you are testing.
>
> Well. If the log is important, I have to go through it, or I miss
> something important. If it is not important (and I don't have to go
> through it) I can skip it altogether. So what do you mean when you
say I
> don't have to go through it?
>
> > Which is why reports are an integral part of a testing framework.
>
> For BDD, I agree.
>
> Robert
>
